moves.1... d6: I respond with Fisher/Reti for black.
moves.2. d4 Nf6 3. Nc3 g6 4. h3: White recognizes the potential for an attack from Bc8.
moves.5... Nbd7 6. Be2 c5 7. Bb5 a6 8. Bxd7+: White offers a bishop in exchange for a knight.
moves.8... Nxd7 9. O-O cxd4:
My notes at this point.  Looking back, I wonder why I didn't take the knight with my bishop and continue to trade pieces.
10. Nxd4 Nf6
11. Nf3 b5
12. Ng5 O-O
13. Qf3 Rb8
moves.10. Nxd4 Nf6: Instead of staying aggressive, I close up the castle again.
moves.13. Nf3 b5 14. a5 Bb7 15. Bb6: White's bishop becomes a firmly planted thorn in my queenside.
At this point, somewhat obviously, I'm trying to simultaneously pressure the g2 and c2 pawns, and I'm feeling pretty good about the move.  But, after I made the move, I saw the folly in it.  In fact, I made a note to myself (as follows) of what might happen if white sees the opportunity for a counter-attack ...
19. Nxe4 Qxe4
20. Qxd6 Rc8
21. Rf-d1 Qf5
... as bad as this is, I didn't recognize the potential for even bigger problems in move 21.
moves.22. Qxa6: My Dad taught me a simple rule a long time ago, never trade pieces when you're behind, unless you have a really good plan for how it's going to help you down the road.  Although this series results in an even score, I'm not sure I had a plan beyond that point.
moves.22... Qc6 23. Qb6 Bxc5:
24. bxc5 Qxc5
25. Qxc5 Rxc5
26. a6 O-O
27. a7 Ra8
moves.24. Qxc5 Qxc5 25. bxc5 Rxc5: A series of trades results in an even score and pressure on c2, but white has a rook behind a pawn, which is a strong position.
moves.26... O-O 27. a7 Ra8: About the only thing I could do.
moves.28. Rfd1: Why oh why didn't I take the c2 pawn?  We'll never know.  It seems so obvious now, but I was apparently concerned about something.
moves.30. Rb7 Ra4 31. Rb1 Ra5 32. Rb1xb5 Rxb5:
33. Rxb5 Rxa7
34. Rxe5 Ra1 
35. Kh2 Rc1
36. Rc5 Kf6
37. c4 Ke6
moves.34... Rc7 35. Re2 Rd7 36. c3 Rd1+:
37. Kh2 Rc1
38. Re3 f5
39. f4 Kf6
40. g3 g5
41. h4 gxf4
42. gxf4 Kg6
43. Kg3 Rg1 
44. Kf3 Rg4
45. c4 Rxh4
46. c5 Rh1
47. Rc3
moves.37. Kh2 Rc1 38. Re3 f5: Not sure what my plan was here, but white wisely exploits the opening to place me in check.
moves.40. Rc7 h5 41. c4 Kf8:
I try to go after the rook, but white evades nicely.
42. c5 Ke8
43. c6 Kd8
44. Rd7  Kc8
45. c7 Kxd7
and now things are really looking grim

gameName: Fisher/Reti for black, trap at move 18 backfires, missed opportunity at 28
